qa_pairs.question: How has the housing crisis affected the community in the Haight area?
qa_pairs.answer: The housing crisis has changed the Haight over the years, shifting the community. Long-term residents being forced to leave takes away the sparkle that is part of the Haight. We are a tight-knit community and it's hard on us when one of them has to leave because rent goes up or some ridiculous thing is happening.
qa_pairs.source_text: the hate has changed over the years because of the housing crisis so be it shifts the community and like people like whove only been here for five years they really freak out about stuff and its like yeah man you need a few more years on you like literally I had someone complaining about the doom and Loom thing of the city and I was like you werent here in the 80s whats going on like this is great uh its like the cycle that we go on as a city like its gonna and um but the idea that some of the long-term residents are forced to leave it takes away that Sparkle that is part of the hate we are a community here more than any place I have ever lived we are like this tight-knit community and we take care of each other we take care of our neighbors and its really hard on us when one of them has to leave because rent goes up or some ridiculous thing is happening that doesnt make sense

qa_pairs.question: What is your view on the cost-effectiveness of preventing homelessness?
qa_pairs.answer: A little bit of money when someone's about to become homeless or about to leave would be much more cost-effective than having the person become homeless. Giving them five thousand dollars to help with two months of rent is much cheaper than having to care for a person when they become homeless.
qa_pairs.source_text: I also think that we need to really stop like a little bit of money when someones about to become homeless or about to leave would really be so much more cost effective than having the person become homeless so like its like that long like stepping back and looking like this like okay yes you might be giving them five thousand dollars to help with two months of rent but thats much cheaper than having to Care House feet like all of these things for a person when they become homeless

qa_pairs.question: What are your thoughts on basic human rights in relation to housing?
qa_pairs.answer: It would be nicer if we had more community housing, food, shelter, water. These are basic human rights that we should all have, and I just don't understand why it hasn't happened yet.
qa_pairs.source_text: it would just be nicer if we had more community housing food shelter water these are basic human rights that we should all have and um I just dont understand why it hasnt happened yet

qa_pairs.question: How has the housing crisis impacted artists in the city?
qa_pairs.answer: The housing crisis has forced a lot of artisans out of the city. It's hard to be an artist in the city; you have to hustle and have multiple side hustles. Some people aren't capable of that, and it can get tiring.
qa_pairs.source_text: I feel like the housing crisis has really forced a lot of The Artisans that used to be in the city out its not easy you know I havent paid myself really in like four years like Im really lucky that I have a situation with my husband that he knows that were working for something bigger and um but man if I had to pay myself Id really be in trouble here uh its its hard to be an artist in the city its hard to be able to live you have to hustle and some people arent capable of that some people need a time out some peoples personality isnt like and like you have to be like that in the city and it can get tiring

qa_pairs.question: What issues do you see with the current parole and housing policies?
qa_pairs.answer: If a family of an incarcerated person is in Section 8 Housing and the person gets out of jail, visiting their family violates parole and they lose the Section 8 housing. This policy doesn't make sense and keeps families apart.
qa_pairs.source_text: or you know if um a family of an incarcerated person is in Section 8 Housing and the person gets out of jail if they want to go see their family it actually violates the parole and they lose the Section 8 housing as well its really dumb so like are we just supposed to keep families like that doesnt even make sense to me I understand if they need to maybe move to a different Section 8 housing that has a different Schnoodle schwarf with the snorf you know that I get but to just lose housing because you want to see someone that you havent seen in the while is not good
